body:
Thanks @pohlt for the report! I can repro the issue, but I cannot detect why this must be the case. I have never used pdm. We set the port here which is based on config options. https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/blob/267bf98d9a8f8d94cf6d3e9f0ea8866233d4836e/lib/streamlit/report.py#L269

So I would imagine pdm is installing in some hidden config or something....Do you have a reference to that issue for `jupyter-lab`? I wonder if it could shed insight on why this might be the case.

Just tried the same setup with pdm and version 0.84.1 of streamlit with the same result.

What's special about how pdm installs packages is the mechanism described in [PEP 582](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0582/). The streamlit files and configurations might not end up where you would normally expect them, I guess.

I'm sorry that I cannot be of more help here.

Hey @pohlt Thank you for following up (and sorry for the delay. I will keep this open for tracking, but we have not prioritized it at the moment. Would love to hear how prevalent PDM is in development workflows and how much this impacts our users.
Closing, as pdm does not come up frequently enough for us to officially support it

issue.title: PDM-installed streamlit fails to launch a server

repository.name: pdm
repository.description: A modern Python package and dependency manager supporting the latest PEP standards

issue.body:
## Steps to reproduce

Add `streamlit` and `watchdog` to a pdm-managed python project. PDM will install the latest version, which as of today is 1.7. Then execute `pdm run streamlit hello` to view the demo.

## Actual behavior

<details>
  <summary> pmd-streamlit hello log </summary>

```
‚ùØ pdm run streamlit hello
2022-03-23 12:03:44.653 WARNING streamlit.config:
Warning: the config option 'server.enableCORS=false' is not compatible with 'server.enableXsrfProtection=true'.
As a result, 'server.enableCORS' is being overridden to 'true'.

More information:
In order to protect against CSRF attacks, we send a cookie with each request.
To do so, we must specify allowable origins, which places a restriction on
cross-origin resource sharing.

If cross origin resource sharing is required, please disable server.enableXsrfProtection.

2022-03-23 12:03:44.658 DEBUG   streamlit.logger: Initialized tornado logs
2022-03-23 12:03:44.661 DEBUG   matplotlib.pyplot: Loaded backend agg version unknown.
2022-03-23 12:03:44.662 DEBUG   streamlit.bootstrap: Setting up signal handler
2022-03-23 12:03:44.662 DEBUG   asyncio: Using selector: KqueueSelector
2022-03-23 12:03:44.676 DEBUG   streamlit.server.server: Starting server...
2022-03-23 12:03:44.676 DEBUG   streamlit.server.server: Serving static content from the Node dev server
2022-03-23 12:03:44.686 DEBUG   streamlit.server.server: Server started on port 8501
2022-03-23 12:03:44.687 DEBUG   streamlit.server.server: Server state: State.INITIAL -> State.WAITING_FOR_FIRST_BROWSER
2022-03-23 12:03:44.848 DEBUG   git.cmd: Popen(['git', 'version'], cwd=/Users/luca/Documents/dev/oai/k2, universal_newlines=False, shell=None, istream=None)
2022-03-23 12:03:44.862 DEBUG   git.cmd: Popen(['git', 'version'], cwd=/Users/luca/Documents/dev/oai/k2, universal_newlines=False, shell=None, istream=None)
2022-03-23 12:03:44.882 DEBUG   git.cmd: Popen(['git', 'version'], cwd=/Users/luca/Documents/dev/oai/k2, universal_newlines=False, shell=None, istream=None)
2022-03-23 12:03:44.895 DEBUG   git.cmd: Popen(['git', 'rev-parse', '--show-toplevel'], cwd=/Users/luca/Documents/dev/oai/k2, universal_newlines=False, shell=None, istream=None)

  Welcome to Streamlit. Check out our demo in your browser.

  Local URL: http://localhost:3000
  Network URL: http://192.168.1.117:3000

  Ready to create your own Python apps super quickly?
  Head over to https://docs.streamlit.io

  May you create awesome apps!


2022-03-23 12:03:44.910 DEBUG   streamlit.version: Skipping PyPI version check
```

</details>

Then, when I connect to `localhost:3000` the connection fails. From my poor server/httpd knowledge, I believe the server does not launch.

## Other attempts

I installed `streamlit` again using `pipx` and when I launch the same command the prompt is much more concise:

<details>
  <summary>pipx-streamlit hello log</summary>

```
‚ùØ streamlit hello

  Welcome to Streamlit. Check out our demo in your browser.

  Local URL: http://localhost:8501
  Network URL: http://192.168.1.117:8501

  Ready to create your own Python apps super quickly?
  Head over to https://docs.streamlit.io

  May you create awesome apps!
```

</details>

**Notably, a different port is chosen: 8501 instead of 3000.**

## Environment Information

```bash
# Paste the output of `pdm info && pdm info --env` below:
PDM version:        1.13.5
Python Interpreter: /Users/luca/.pyenv/versions/3.9.9/bin/python (3.9)
Project Root:       /Users/luca/Documents/dev/oai/k2
Project Packages:   /Users/luca/Documents/dev/oai/k2/__pypackages__/3.9
{
  "implementation_name": "cpython",
  "implementation_version": "3.9.9",
  "os_name": "posix",
  "platform_machine": "x86_64",
  "platform_release": "21.4.0",
  "platform_system": "Darwin",
  "platform_version": "Darwin Kernel Version 21.4.0: Mon Feb 21 20:34:37 PST 2022; root:xnu-8020.101.4~2/RELEASE_X86_64",
  "python_full_version": "3.9.9",
  "platform_python_implementation": "CPython",
  "python_version": "3.9",
  "sys_platform": "darwin"
}
```

body:
I found a way that works: https://github.com/pdm-project/pdm/issues/989#issuecomment-1078293607. Hopefully it's not only for me, but for everyone.

Actually PDM is getting more and more popular recently. It would be great if it could be supported officially.

It looks like @AnOctopus is an enthusiast and is working towards this:

https://github.com/pdm-project/pdm/issues/972

I'll re-open, so everyone can be aware that its been requested.

> I found a way that works: [pdm-project/pdm#989 (comment)](https://github.com/pdm-project/pdm/issues/989#issuecomment-1078293607). Hopefully it's not only for me, but for everyone.
> 
> Actually PDM is getting more and more popular recently. It would be great if it could be supported officially.

That workaround gives me a very good idea about the source of the problem. We automatically set development mode by trying to detect how streamlit was installed, and I suspect being installed into `__pypackages__` breaks our heuristics for that. Should be relatively easy to fix.

@AnOctopus Thanks for the reply! Glad it helps. I realized the workaround is not ideal since with `--global.developmentMode false`, I'm not able to see live updates when I modify the code. I have to stop and relaunch the app to reflect the update. Hopefully in the future `pdm run streamlit run app.py` could simply work. üòÜ

issue.title: streamlit's webserver not working when using BAZEL for installation bug

labels.name: type:enhancement
labels.description: Requests for feature enhancements or new features

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
### Summary

Related to https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues/3132 .

An internal check to see if streamlit is running in development mode or not. This checks if some strings are present in the script's file path. This check is not valid for other installation types, e.g. bazel.

The script path in a bazel build is for example:
`/home/{user}/.cache/bazel/_bazel_{user}/b775940771a888524b9eed82a7f43708/execroot/{organization}/bazel-out/k8-fastbuild/bin/apps/daq/streamlit_main.runfiles/pip_deps_pypi__streamlit/streamlit/hello/hello.py`

This could be solved by also checking for "pip_deps_pypi__streamlit" in the development_mode check, or by just having a better check in general.

### Steps to reproduce

Code snippet:

streamlit_main.py
```
import sys
from streamlit import cli as stcli

if __name__ == '__main__':
    sys.argv = ["streamlit", "hello"]
    sys.exit(stcli.main())

```

BUILD.bazel
```python
load("@rules_python//python:defs.bzl", "py_binary")

py_binary(
    name = "streamlit_main",
    srcs = [
        "streamlit_main.py",
    ],
    main = "streamlit_main.py",
    visibility = ["//visibility:public"],
    deps = [
        requirement('streamlit')
    ],
)
```
If applicable, please provide the steps we should take to reproduce the bug:

run "bazel build streamlit_main"

**Expected behavior:**

To not run in development mode;

**Actual behavior:**

Runs in development mode. 

### Is this a regression?

no

### Debug info

- Streamlit version: 1.8.1
- Python version: 3.7
- Using Conda? PipEnv? PyEnv? Pex? BAZEL
- OS version: Ubuntu 20.04
- Browser version:

### Additional information

Workaround: explicitly set developmentMode to false:

```
import sys
from streamlit import cli as stcli

if __name__ == '__main__':
    sys.argv = ["streamlit", "hello", "--global.developmentMode", "0"]
    sys.exit(stcli.main())

```

issue.title: Detect being installed in `__pypackages__`

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
The install location won't have site-packages or dist-packages in it, so
check for `__pypackages__` as well. 

## üìö Context

- What kind of change does this PR introduce?

  - [x] Bugfix
  - [ ] Feature
  - [ ] Refactoring
  - [ ] Other, please describe:

## üß† Description of Changes

- Check for being installed in `__pypackages__` (PEP582 install location)

  - [ ] This is a breaking API change
  - [x] This is a visible (user-facing) change

## üß™ Testing Done

- [ ] Screenshots included
- [ ] Added/Updated unit tests
- [ ] Added/Updated e2e tests

## üåê References

- **Issue**: Closes #3132

issue.title: Unable to run scripts with pdm

labels.name: status:confirmed
labels.description: Bug has been confirmed by the Streamlit team

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
### Summary

Streamlit scripts cannot run properly through pdm.

### Steps to reproduce

Code snippet:

```
import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

st.title('Uber pickups in NYC')
```

Enter the following command in the terminal of vscode:

```
pdm run streamlit run uber_pickups.py
```

**Expected behavior:**

This is an example program in the official document, which should work properly.

**Actual behavior:**

The following traceback:

```
$ pdm run streamlit run uber_pickups.py
2022-05-10 18:09:13.890 WARNING streamlit.config: 
Warning: the config option 'server.enableCORS=false' is not compatible with 'server.enableXsrfProtection=true'.
As a result, 'server.enableCORS' is being overridden to 'true'.

More information:
In order to protect against CSRF attacks, we send a cookie with each request.
To do so, we must specify allowable origins, which places a restriction on
cross-origin resource sharing.

If cross origin resource sharing is required, please disable server.enableXsrfProtection.
            
2022-05-10 18:09:13.891 DEBUG   streamlit.logger: Initialized tornado logs
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/skahanium/Desktop/test/streamlit test/__pypackages__/3.10/bin/streamlit", line 8, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/opt/homebrew/lib/python3.10/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1130, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/opt/homebrew/lib/python3.10/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1055, in main
    rv = self.invoke(ctx)
  File "/opt/homebrew/lib/python3.10/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1657, in invoke
    return _process_result(sub_ctx.command.invoke(sub_ctx))
  File "/opt/homebrew/lib/python3.10/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1404, in invoke
    return ctx.invoke(self.callback, **ctx.params)
  File "/opt/homebrew/lib/python3.10/site-packages/click/core.py", line 760, in invoke
    return __callback(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/skahanium/Desktop/test/streamlit test/__pypackages__/3.10/lib/streamlit/cli.py", line 204, in main_run
    _main_run(target, args, flag_options=kwargs)
  File "/Users/skahanium/Desktop/test/streamlit test/__pypackages__/3.10/lib/streamlit/cli.py", line 232, in _main_run
    command_line = _get_command_line_as_string()
  File "/Users/skahanium/Desktop/test/streamlit test/__pypackages__/3.10/lib/streamlit/cli.py", line 221, in _get_command_line_as_string
    cmd_line_as_list.extend(click.get_os_args())
AttributeError: module 'click' has no attribute 'get_os_args'
```

### Is this a regression?

Don't know

### Debug info

- Streamlit version: 1.9.0
- Python version: 3.10.2
- Using PDM(Python Development Master) version: 1.14.1
- OS version: MacOS Monterey 12.3.1
- Browser version: Safari 15.4

### Additional information

I tried to return the click version to 8.0.0 and 7.1.2 as suggested by some people in the forum, but it didn't work. Later, an attempt to downgrade streamlit to version 1.8.0 was still ineffective.
